EXT, SWISS SNOW CLAD MOUNTAINS. DAY. 125
RIMMER, HUTCHISON, SPOT, SIR ERIC'S NEPHEW, LADY VANYA,

PROMISES PRESIDENTIAL REFERENDUM, NO MORE AFTER THIS',

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old-fashioned office entrance with RECEPTIONIST also working the switchboard. BUFFERY, a client, enters followed closely by MICHAEL RIMMER who contrives to give the impression they are together, RIMMER carries a clipboard and stopwatch. A board says 'FAIRBURN OPINION POLLS', "FAIRBURN MANAGEMENT’, etc.

dialogues.speaker: BUFFERY
dialogues.text: (politely) I'd like to see the Managing Director please. Buffery's the name.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Just one moment. (she presses intercom. button) Mr. Ferret?

dialogues.speaker: FERRET'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (over intercom.) With cream please.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: No, Mr. Ferret ...

dialogues.speaker: FERRET'S VOICE
dialogues.text: But I always have cream, and sugar.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: There's a Mr. Buffery to see you.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Oh, send him up please.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (to BUFFERY) Third floor please. (to RIMMER) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Yes. RIMMER walks away with BUFFERY.  INT. STAIRCASE. DAY. RIMMER follows, BUFFERY and times his ascent with a stop- watch. An embarrassing silence for BUFFERY as they continue up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RIMMER follows BUFFERY along corridor and enters FERRET's office behind him. FERRET, the Managing Director, is a struggling member of the respectable middle class. INT, OFFICE. DAY. TANYA who is FERRET's very sexy secretary is seated at desk in same office.

dialogues.speaker: BUFFERY
dialogues.text: Mr, Ferret?

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Yes. FERRET smiles, puts out his hand. BUFFERY punches FERRET in the face,knocking him back off his chair, turns to leave the office and stops at the door.

dialogues.speaker: BUFFERY
dialogues.text: Just popped in to cancel our contract. BUFFERY exits,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: (smiling) Good morning, Mr. Ferret.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: (struggling to get up) Good morning ... You alright? e© w+. er.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Rimmer Sir - Co-ordination. CONTINUED ;  CONTD. FERRET . Ah yes, keep it up ... vital work. RIMMER leaves, FERRET turns and looks at his files.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Co-ordination? INT. CORRIDOR. DAY. RIMMER goes down corridor passing door marked “CHIEF STATISTICIAN” N. CRODDER. We hear u strangled cry of "God" from within. He stops at door marked J. MORRISON, Public Relations. INT. MORRISON'S OFFICE. DAY. RIMMER opens door with considerable difficulty. We see an office covered in cobwebs. Moths flit to and fro amidst the dust, INT. CORRIDOR/OFFICE. DAY. RIMMER closes door and proceeds to Accounts Office. He opens door to discover Chief Accountant FEDERMANN, who is on 'phore. The room has the atmosphere and equipment of an old fashioned betting shop.

dialogues.speaker: FEDERMANN
dialogues.text: I'll just read those figures back. Two pounds to win on Lively Lady. And a fiver on the Groper ... (notices RIMMER) Ah, ha ... good morning.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: (smiling) Good morning. It's Mr. Federman isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: FEDERMANN
dialogues.text: Yes, RIMMER notes something down on his clipboard and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: . Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: INT, LAVATORY. DAY. 8
dialogues.text: RIMMER enters lavatory and takes up position by door. PUMER enters,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: (smiling) Mr. Pumer?

dialogues.speaker: PUMER
dialogues.text: Yes ... who are you?

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Rimmer, Co-ordination ... please carry on, PUMER goes to pee, puzzled. As he begins RIMMER clicks stopwatch. BEGIN TITLES. PUMER finishes. RIMMER clocks stopwatch again and notes down findings. Exit PUMER, disturbed. RIMMER tests automatic towel dispenser. The entire roll falls out. RIMMER makes a note. Enter FEDERMANN,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Hello again, Mr. Federmann.

dialogues.speaker: FEDERMANN
dialogues.text: Oh, hello, FEDERMANN goes into cubicle, RIMMER clocks stopwatch then wanders about noting efficiency of taps, plugs, liquid soap containers etc. None of them work. FEDERMANN pulls chain: it does not work first two times and when it does, makes an appalling gurgling roar. RIMMER clicks stopwatch and makes note. FEDERMANN leaves embarrassedly,

dialogues.speaker: FEDERMANN
dialogues.text: Ah, well, back to the grindstane,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RIMMER goes into cubicle and climbs up on seat to inspect the faulty cistern, Enter CRODDER. He goes into next door cubicle, takes his trousers down, and is about to begin when he seas RIMMER above him. He leaves cubicle looking worried.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) Won't be a moment. He completes operation end gets down for a test flush, this is satisfactory.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Would you mind using this one, Mr, er oa.

dialogues.speaker: CRODDER
dialogues.text: Crodder. CRODDER enters cubicle but does not quite shut the door, through the crack he peers at RIMMER as he clocks his stopwatch.

dialogues.speaker: CRODDER
dialogues.text: Good God! Is nothing sacred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TANYA is coming down the corridor as CRODDER emerges.

dialogues.speaker: CRODDER
dialogues.text: Extraordinary thing just happened in the john! I went in and there was a fellow there with a stopwatch.

dialogues.speaker: TANYA
dialogues.text: That's Mr, Rimmer, co-ordination.

dialogues.speaker: CRODDER
dialogues.text: Is he one of those ghastly Time and i 2 Motion people? CONTINUED:  10

dialogues.speaker: TANYA
dialogues.text: I think he's working for Mr. Fairburn himself, RIMMER appears.

dialogues.speaker: CRODDER
dialogues.text: (obsequiously) Good morning ... Well mustn't hang about ... lots to do. Two men, FROMAGE and WARING, are advancing purposefully down the corridor. TANYA leads them to FERRET's office. RIMMER follows them in.

dialogues.speaker: TANYA
dialogues.text: Mr. Fromage and Mr, Waring, Mr. Ferret. They've come about the advertising.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Ah, good morning! FERRET goes to his desk and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: i expect you've come about the advertising.

dialogues.speaker: WARING
dialogues.text: Yes, we have.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Ah good, Well, I will just get the man in charge of advertising.

dialogues.speaker: WARING
dialogues.text: No, Mr. Ferret, we have come to see you.

dialogues.speaker: FROMAGE
dialogues.text: Yes, we've come to make a complaint. CONTINUED;  10 CONTD.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Ah,well, I'll get the man in charge : of complaints.

dialogues.speaker: WARING
dialogues.text: No, Mr. Ferret, we want to see you,

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Ah well, you've come to the right man then,

dialogues.speaker: WARING
dialogues.text: Just over six months ago, Mr. Ferret, you undertook our new advertising campaign. We heard from you for the first time yesterday. You sent us some slogans for advertising our dog food,

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: WARING
dialogues.text: We don't make dog food, Mr. Ferret, we make humbugs.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Oh, and you're not thinking of branching out into dog food?

dialogues.speaker: WARING
dialogues.text: No, and if we were, we would want something more original than “Woof makes doggies bounce with health",

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Do get that typewriter fixed, Tanya.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: We are working on a new presentation concept, Mr. Waring. Mr. Ferret will have it ready in a week.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: «++ one week it is ... make a note Tanya.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: (ushering them out) Thank you gentlemen. Here's my card... if you'd like to call next Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see RIMMER in longshot in earnest, efficient conversation with FROMAGE and WARING in corridor. As they leave we hear the strains of tango music. RIMMER goes down corridor and stops at PUMER's door. From inside the office comes the strain of Victor Sylvester Music, RIMMER listens fur a moment and then opeus the door quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside is PUMER wearing tails, carnation, learning the steps of the TANGO. On the floor he has chalked out foot positions and as RIMMER watches he starts a series of steps. These involve him in a turn during which he sights RIMMER, double take, turns again, double take, turns again.

dialogues.speaker: PUMER
dialogues.text: (pointing to marks on the floor) Tango. My wife and I have been selected for the South East. I practise in the coffee break, I don't have coffee.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: (taking a note on his clipboard) Pumer with an 'e' isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: PUMER
dialogues.text: Well, just the one 'e’ ... well, coffee break over. PUMER replaces tails on coat hanger.  13 14

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RIMMER sees CRODDER entering lavatory. He follows him in and clocks watch as CRODDER enters cubicle. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: CRODDER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You can stay there all day if you like. I can't do anything under these conditions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRET is pretending to get a file, whilst fumbling near TANYA's legs. RIMMER approaches and watches from the bottom of a small staircase.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Um ... thank you, Tanya, that'll be all I'm afraid. FERRET motions TANYA away, she walks down the stairs to FERRET's office.

dialogues.speaker: TANYA
dialogues.text: All right, Mr. Ferret.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: If it's all right by you, I'll take over the office next door to you.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Oh good! Yes, look, I'll tell you what, why don't you take it over?

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Thank you. FERRET looks at his watch and walks down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Ah well must be off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRET goes into office, goes to mirror and notices lipstick marks and turns on tap in washbasin. Water

dialogues.speaker: CONTD.
dialogues.text: comes out. Suddenly stops.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Tanya, what have you done with my water?

dialogues.speaker: TANYA
dialogues.text: The Water Board have cut it off, sir,

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: What have we ever done to them?

dialogues.speaker: TANYA
dialogues.text: We haven't paid them, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Money, money, money. Whatever's the world coming to? (slightly furtively to Tanya as RIMMER walks away in corridor) See you in the pub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRET is kneeling at coca cola machine, cleaning lipstick off with coke and flannel. PUMER, FEDERMANN leave and TANYA walks out of office and down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: They'll be cutting the electricity off next. The corridor is plunged into darkness. Confusion. Darkness is pierced only by the beam of RIMMER's torch. We see FERRET walk into a fire extinguisher by the light of this.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Mr. Ferret.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Ah Rimmer. I was just conducting a little experiment; on the effect on office efficiency of total darkness. i wouldn't bother to tell Mr. Fairburn about it, he's a bit out of touch with modern methods,  11.

dialogues.speaker: CRODDER
dialogues.text: (shouting plaintively) It's no good turning the lights out. I know you're still there.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FERRET'S HOUSE, NIGHT. 17
dialogues.text: FERRET staggers to front door. It is opened by MRS, FERRE

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FERRET
dialogues.text: Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Well lots of places, Paris, Rome ...

dialogues.speaker: MRS, FERRET
dialogues.text: Tonight.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Ah, tonight, I was working late.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FERRET
dialogues.text: I rang the office and they said you weren't there.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Really? Who did you speak to?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FERRET
dialogues.text: A Mr. Rimmer,

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Ah yes, as I was working late I told him to say that I wasn't there. Full marks to Rimmer.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FERRET
dialogues.text: You come in here reeking of sex and scent and with a love bite on your neck.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: It's not scent dear nor is it a love bite. I happened to be washing my face with coca cola when the lights went out and I banged my neck on the fire extinguisher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People arriving at the office and treating RIMMER with respect and obsequiousness, as he ticks off their names on a clipboard. TANYA arrives. Workmen are busy pulling down walls,

dialogues.speaker: TANYA
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Rimmer, TANGO MUSIC AS PUMER ENTERS DANCING, He eases into a normal walk as he sees RIMMER.

dialogues.speaker: PUMER
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: INT, RIMMER'S OFFICE. DAY. 19
dialogues.text: RIMMER is on the "phone. New office equipment is being brought in and old stuff removed. Workmen are knocking down walls. TANYA is also there.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: The report on Davidson and Cubbey please Tanya, (TANYA goes to cabinet) and could I have the appreciation figure for last month? ‘Thank you, RIMMER feeds them into the adding machine and picks up €@ second ‘phone,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Sorry to keep you Mr. Wilde; my secretary's just getting the file, can I call you back? Another 'phone rings. RIMMER (Cont'd.) Hello ... yes, Mr, Tibalt ... It must have slipped Mr. Ferret's mind ... I'll get it done right away ... goodbye. Any sign of Mr. Ferret, Tanya?  20

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRET passing reception desk looking at his watch. Various workmen are knocking down walls - a new elevator is being installed.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Good morning ... terrible traffic today. Terrible traffic yesterday ... just like last week.

dialogues.speaker: INT, CORRIDOR. DAY. 21
dialogues.text: FERRET appears at top of the stairs still muttering about the terrible traffic. CRODDER stops him.

dialogues.speaker: CRODDER
dialogues.text: Can't stop ... it's all go this morning.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Terrible traffic.

dialogues.speaker: CRODDER
dialogues.text: Mr. Rimmer's anxious to see you.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Ah good ... As FERRET passes RIMMER's office he raises his brief case to obscure his face. We can clearly see R.J. FERRET embossed on the leather,

dialogues.speaker: INT, RIMMER'S OFFICE, DAY. 22
dialogues.text: From RIMMER's office we see FERRET enter his own office next door through enormous holes in the wall. FERRET sits down and swings feet on to desk.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Mr. Ferret?

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Ah,..didn't see you there. Sorry about the hole in the wall. Terrible traffic.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD. RIMMER
dialogues.text: Could you let me have the results of the Wheatieflake survey?

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Not as such ... but I've got the one on boot polish.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: And what does it show?

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: It shows ... er ... well itsshows that about 90% of English families don't like boot polish for breakfast ,.. I'm afraid there was a bit of a muddle about the questionnaires... I'll look into it right away. FERRET gets up.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: I'd rather you didn't. FERRET sits down.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Right ... I'll ... er not look into it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FAIRBURN'S STATELY HOME. DAY. 23
dialogues.text: RIMER draws up in a taxi, FAIRBURN's old fashioned Rolls Royce stands in the driver. RIMMER gets out of the taxi and puts on his smart pair of Wellington boots.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FAIRBURN'S HOUSE BY LAKE, DAY. 24
dialogues.text: RIMMER approaches FAIRBURN who is determinedly fly fishin in the middle of stream/lake. RIMMER walks into the water and stands by FAIRBURN.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: I've got it all here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBURN
dialogues.text: (involved with fish) What? Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it's only the preliminary findings, I haven't had much time.

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBURN
dialogues.text: Is this one of Ferret's damn fool ideas?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 24 CONTD. 15.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: No sir, it's the business efficiency report you commissioned.

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBURN
dialogues.text: I did no such thing, I've never seen you before in my life.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Yes, I think your decision to investigate was very timely.

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBURN
dialogues.text: Was it? Ah, it was timely was it? Yes. Well that's what decisions should be. It seemed to have slipped my mind and my wife's been rather under the weather.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Nothing serious I hope.

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBURN
dialogues.text: No, no, I think she'll linger on for quite a while yet.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: (handing over a file) Here's the report sir.

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBURN
dialogues.text: It's a bit long ... could you give me a rundown I'm a bit busy today.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Well, sir, the firm seems to be running an annual deficit of some seventy-five thousand pounds.

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBURN
dialogues.text: Seventy-five thousand pounds! My god. Well do you know the words that come to my mind!

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: No sir, I don't know the words,

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBURN
dialogues.text: Fire Ferret. Those are the words. Fire Ferret. FAIRBURN storms out of the water closely followed by RIMM

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FAIRBURN BUILDING. DAY. 25
dialogues.text: Rolls Royce draws up, FAIRBURN and RIMMER get out and enter offices. People treat them with great respect.

dialogues.speaker: INT, FERRET'S OFFICE. DAY. 26
dialogues.text: FERRET in office at his desk. He is watching cricket on the T.V. with a plate of half eaten cream buns in front of him. There is a buzz on the intercom. He finishes the bun and flicks the switch.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (through intercom) Mx. Fairburn to see you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: I'm busy.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: But it's Mr. Fairburn, sir. He wants to see you now.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: I don't care if its Mr. Fairburn himself... Oh it is! Ah, I see. Er, um. Tell him I'm with a client. Give me five minutes, FERRET flicks off the switch and starts to clear away. The door flies open. FERRET starts, see FAIRBURN and in one movement flicks whole plate of buns behind the T.V. set.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Ah Mr. Fairbun.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 26 CONTD.

dialogues.speaker: FATRBURN
dialogues.text: Fairburn.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Fairburn, yes, yes, my client just left unexpectedly by the back...escape,. FERRET switches T.V. set off, FERRET (Cont'd. ) We're doing market research about people watching cricket on the T.V. Yes ... so do sit down Mx. Creambun ++. Fairburn! Throw those old files somewhere, FAIRBURN sits down, RIMMER stands behind him. A long menacing silence. FERRET laughs wildly.

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBURN
dialogues.text: What are you laughing at Ferret?

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Just er ... nothing.... I was trying to break the ice.

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBURN
dialogues.text: I've been looking into the annual accounts...

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Ah yes, well about the deficit ...

dialogues.speaker: FATRBURN
dialogues.text: I'm coming to that.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Ah ... you're coming to that. FERRET flicks the intercom. He's coming to that.

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBURN
dialogues.text: You're fired. i CONTINUED:  18. 26 CONTD. 2.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: How about that, well I must be off then.

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBURN
dialogues.text: One moment Ferret: about the deficit. FERRET flicks intercom.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: He's come to that.

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBURN
dialogues.text: It's enormous.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: So it is ... huge ... well. FERRET rises to leave.

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBURN
dialogues.text: £75,000, It amounts to criminal negligence.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: £75,000 ... that igs a lot (tries to leave)

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBURN
dialogues.text: You owe me a lot of money Ferret! And you will remain with this firm working very hard in a menial capacity for a pittance until such time as I decide you have worked off your debt. Otherwise it will be P.R.1I.S.0.N.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Ah, Prison.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 26 27 28 29 19. CONTD, 3. As RIMMER and FAIRBURN leave.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Good thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FAIRBURN bangs the office door.

dialogues.speaker: FAIRBURN
dialogues.text: I should put Ferret in charge of cleaning; he can't do much damage there. A tremendous crash comes from FERRET's office as cupboard falls over,

dialogues.speaker: INT, FERRET'S OFFICE, DAY, 28
dialogues.text: FERRET is trapped under cupboard,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: (looking in on FERRET) I'm sorry about all that unpleasantness «e+ why dog't you take the afternoon off.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FERRET
dialogues.text: What do you mean by coming home at this hour?

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: What hour?

dialogues.speaker: MRS, FERRET
dialogues.text: Two o'clock in the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Anyway I'm home early for a change.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FERRET
dialogues.text: Have you been fired?

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Fired? Ha ha, Fired??? Ha, ha, ha, near to it. I mean far from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TANYA showing FROMAGE and WARING into RIMMER's office. RIMMER at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Ah Mr. Waring, Mr. Fromage, do sit down. I have the results of our survey into why the sales of Olde English Humbugs are declining.

dialogues.speaker: WARING
dialogues.text: You can be frank with us ... what does it show?

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: The consumer strongly dislikes the taste of your product, furthermore it's extreme hardness makes it almost impossible to eat.

dialogues.speaker: FROMAGE
dialogues.text: That's very true.

dialogues.speaker: WARING
dialogues.text: Nobody knows that better than us.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: But I thiak it might be possible to make a virtue out of these faults with the right kind of campaign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen shows a very sexy girl, lying obviously naked under a sheet on a large double bed; she is tossing and turning restlessly.

dialogues.speaker: 30B
dialogues.text: al.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD,
dialogues.text: V.a, What's keeping him? Why doesn't he come, Suddenly she remembers her tube of Scorpios, She reaches for her bag on the bedside table, unzips it and langorously withdraws a silver tube, she caresses the top and squeezes out a mint which she places sensuous in her mouth; she begins to chew, a look of mounting excitement on her face. V.0. The refreshing hardness tingles on her tongue; she doesn't need him any more.

dialogues.speaker: V.O. CHOIR SINGING,
dialogues.text: Scorpio, the mint that lingers longer in the mouth. She is now obviously satisfied. V.0. Enjoy yourself, with a Scorpio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights come up. FROMAGE and WARING are impressed and randy,

dialogues.speaker: FROMAGE
dialogues.text: Good God! Is that our old Humbug! Enter FERRET with tray.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Here's the coffze you asked for, sir.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: It was tea, Ferret.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: 4h tea was it? Well I think there may be some tea in it.

dialogues.speaker: GONTD,
dialogues.text: FERRET reaches the safety of the door.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET

PUMER leans down and taps on his maskand points at list, FROGMAN mouths 'Fuck Off' through visor, PUMER looks puzzled. INT. SLEAZY ROOM. DAY. Tart clearing away some whips,

dialogues.text: INT. FERRET'S HOUSE. DAY. 4l FERRET at breakfast table reading the Daily News Sex Poll Newspaper. Headlines read "Sex and the British. Yes, It's Randy Britain . You've never had it so often."

dialogues.speaker: FERRET

dialogues.speaker: FERRET

dialogues.speaker: INT, TELEVISION STUDIO. NIGHT. 42
dialogues.text: The STEVEN HENCH show is in progress. A studio audience. HENCH is seated between MICHAEL RIMMER and PETER NISS of International Opinion Polls. PERCY EDWARDS has just completed his bird imitation,

dialogues.text: Good night. Tu whit tu wu. The audience applauds. HENCH smiles and claps; then very serious into camera,

dialogues.text: 42 CONTD.

HENCH (Cont 'd.) A sensational Poll this morning purports to give the answers. I have with me Mr. Michael Rimmer of Fairburn Polls and Peter Niss of the rival International Opinion Polls. I have the feeling Mr. Rimmer ..,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Congratulations. The studio audience laugh.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: I get the impression that you conducted this survey because you felt that this kind of scientifically disguised smut would get your firm maximum puhlicity,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Could you tell me why you've invited me on the programme?

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: To find out your real motives for publishing the poll.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: And to talk about sex.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: Do lets try not to be frivolous.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Sex may be frivolous to you Mr. Niss... but its not for me ... or for that matter, the vast majority of people in this country,

dialogues.speaker: NISS

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Yes I do ... I think everybody's interested...

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: Well it's not the sort of Poll that we could conduct at I.0.P.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: I think, that's a pity because the more we know about what people really feel and want, the better. This is the only way we're going to be able to adapt our society to fit its real needs. I think Polls are only beginning.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: Now lets see how our audience feels. HENCH takes hand mike and goes into audience. He approach a man who obviously doesn't want to talk, hiding his face behind his hands.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: You sir ... what do you think about publicising people's personal sexual habits. The man still hidden shakes his head and tries to wave HENCH away.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: Ah you seem to disapprove ... wonder if your wife agrees. HENCH turns to woman next to him.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (stage whispering) I'm not his wife .ss go away. Woman pushes HENCH away. ®  43 30.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: Yes...ha, ha, ha...poor sods.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Thank you...I'm glad you enjoyed it... how very sweet of you ... next week's a bit tricky ..right, breakfast 8 o'clock at the zoo. He puts the phone down and rubs hands together.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER

dialogues.speaker: HENCH

dialogues.speaker: CONTD,
