dialogues.text: Now. attempts to weep producing handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: We can fix the tears. Don't worry. Next heckle. (glances at sheet) (sings Red Flag) «..We'll keep the Red Flag flying here. RIMMER and NISS sing the Red Flag - alternate lines.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Thank you for that charming rendition, but I don't think the group is ready to record yet. RIMMER and NISS clap and do forced hearty laughs.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: does terrible emile.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: Lose the smile.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: And I would remind our young vocalists of the left that red is also the colour of blood, blood that was shed in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 59 CONTD. 2.
HUTCHISON (Cont'd.) Hungary and Czechoslovakia by the Russian oppressors.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Appleuse, applause, applause, very good, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NISS is walking through sports grounds with RANJIT 'K', a student leader. Students can be seen practising rioting techniques such as; throwing marbles under horses’ hooves Throwing stones at knock down fairground cut~out policeme Striking people with peace signs. Small groups being lectured. One group shouting "Fascist Pig" at pig with swastika on it, led by U.S. Student. Signs such as ‘Che lives', etc.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: And how did you persuade the authorities to establish a Faculty of Applied Violence?

dialogues.speaker: RANJIT X
dialogues.text: Direct action ... its the only way ...with the minimum of non-violence. (to student) U.S. plus napalm equals what?

dialogues.speaker: U.S. STUDENT
dialogues.text: Fascism, Ranjit.

dialogues.speaker: RANJIT X
dialogues.text: First class Gary ... now as I understand it, you guarantee maximum TV and press coverage, travel expenses and a bonus for speaking parts.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: (Handing over sheafs of paper) And of course your usual personal appearance fee.

dialogues.speaker: RANJIT X
dialogues.text: Don't lets talk about bourgeois things like money please ... speak to my agent Spout ite (MORE) CONTINUED :

dialogues.speaker: CONTD,.
dialogues.text: RANJIT X (Cont'd.) (shouts at students lying passively on ground) Get up! None of that old Ghandi rubbish, get up and hit someone! Oh Che, forgive them for they know not what they do. They have now reached Podium, RANJIT X (Cont'd. Could you all come over here please ... would the group singing "We shall not be moved" move over here at the double please...Fellow students...next week the Conservative Party is holding its annual conference ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HUTCHISON and RIMMER who is about to Mount Podium.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Hold on to the handkerchief ... and no smiling.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: I've never felt less like smiling in my life. RANJIT X organising Hecklers. Chairman stands up.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the next Prime Minister of Great Britain, the leader of the Conservative Party, Tom Hutchison. Mild applause. HUTCHISON stands up. Cut to Hecklers preparing missiles.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen (tomato and eggs begin to rain on him) Ladies and gentlemen,

dialogues.speaker: CONTD,
dialogues.text: There is mounting uproar, Chairman leaps to feet.

dialogues.speaker: . CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Order! Order! Order! Cut to strong arm men moving toward Hecklers, who have begun singing The Red Flag. RANJIT X is thrown bodily out of the door and down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: No, no I would ask the ushers not to eject our friends of the left, the Conservative Party believes in the freedom of speech, I wish they did! A good round of applause as the noise dies down, we still hear people singing The Red Flag. It dies out.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Thank you for that charming rendition, but I don't think the group is ready to record yet! And I would remind our young vocalists of the left that red is also the colour of blood, blood that was shed in Hungary and Czechoslovakia by the Russian oppressors. A very big round of applause and cheering. Cut to RIMMER sitting in audience with NISS.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Going very well.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: And now if I may turn to Economic matters... A very old woman gets to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: What about the old age pensions? At this moment HUTCHISON makes "his turn' to the gallery. The old woman is in the body of the hall.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: (alarmed) That's not in the script.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: What about the old age pensions? CONTINUED:

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Don't talk to me about unemployment young man. I was unemployed before you were born. (Sensation) Audience. What? What? What?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: My memory of those terrible days in the thirties still brings tears to my eyes, He immediately raises handkerchief to his eyes. We see a bottle inside the handkerchief. He dabs eyes with it. Tears appear. He then places handkerchief in front of him and continues with difficulty. And I and the whole of the Conservative Party are strong committed and I emphasise this ... He thumps table but hits handkerchief and shatters bottle of tear inducer. The fumes quickly spread to the other Ministers who begin weeping. We are committed to a policy of full employment ... (sobbing) Lower taxation ... social justice ... and ... and I'm sorry. All the Ministers are in tears now and it is beginning to affect the front row of the audience.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: And ... and ...

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: He can't read the notes ... start the applause. NISS rises to feet and starts applauding.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: 7 minutes, pass it along. The words "7 MINUTES" are passed along the rows of delegates: Intercut ... shots of weeping Ministers.  52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . Amidst amazing scenes at the Conservative Party Conference this afternoon, the Leader of the Opposition was accorded an unprecedented seven minutes ovation. Mr. Hutchison your position as Leader must now be completely secure. How do you feel about the violent heckling that punctuated your speech?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: (pink eyed) I'm not saying the Labour Party was © responsible for this disgraceful episode but I will say this. It certainly seemed to be organised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: mn HUTCHISON, RIMMER and NISS emerge from caravan grinnin They walk through a barrage of photographers then along pier.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: So far so good.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: S What is the next move, Michael?

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Well at the moment I've got my personal life to consider. Amazed reaction from NISS.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: I'm thinking of getting married.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: ~ Congratulations Michael.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: I think an M.P. needs a wife, at his side.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Quite right.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: That I'm not sure of yet. Peter, have you got the results of that Poll? NISss Yes. Queen number one as usual... He hands over folder with photographs attached. RIMMER reads,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Number two, second most popular girl in Britain, Pat Cartwright ... the show jumper ... hum ... good.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: Love at first sight.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Pretty girl isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: You romantic fool you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RIMMER arrives in Jensen Director. TANYA is working in th secretary's seat. Horse training corral of large English country house. PAT CARTWRIGHT is riding round on a stalli RIMMER calls out and she rides over and dismounts. W hear end of short conversation.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Would you like to come in and have a drink. My parents would love to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Gorgeous, but I've got to dash to see the Prime Minister - What about dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RIMMER arrives in sports car, and parks it conspicuously badly. He walks to the door of No. 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACKET, the Prime Minister is reading PREDICTION and laying out his TARO cards.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKET
dialogues.text: Hello, Michael, nice of you to come.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: It's a pleasure, Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: BLACRET
dialogues.text: Tell me Michael ... have you ever thought of going into politics? We're always on the look out for fresh blood ... and there are one or two seats available.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: I've never really thought of myself as a socialist.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKET
dialogues.text: I don't see why that should be an impediment; we're not bound by dogma, Think it over ... the offer's there ... now then my spies tell me ... not literally of course (switches on concealed tape recorder) that your firm has been investigating the reasons for the slight decline in the popularity of my Government.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it's you sir,

dialogues.speaker: BLACKET
dialogues.text: But your polls have always shown me as more popular than the Government as a whole.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Exactly, the public haven't been seeing enough of you: you've been off our TV screens for quite a while now.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKET
dialogues.text: Well I try to give the impression that we work as a team.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: But every team needs a leader.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKET
dialogues.text: True ... so you think a little more exposure on the silvery tube...

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: The more the better.,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACKET is talking on T.V. RIMMER and PAT are watching.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKET
dialogues.text: A lot has happened since 10 o'clock this morning, so I thought it was about time we had another of our little fireside chats.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Never seen a man dig his own grave before.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Oh, turn him off Michael.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 66 a ® ao

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 69 56. cONTD. RIMMER switches him off with remote control device. He presses another button and soft music comes up and the lights dim gently. RIMMER nuzzles her neck and with mock sincerity says:

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: I must tell you how much I've admired your seat ... it's been an inspiration to me. Kiss, kiss. He starts on her buttons.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: No ... stop it ... we mustn't ...

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Cnee doesn't count as breaking training.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: But I've got the Olympic heats tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: I've got the Olympic heats tonight ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music mounts to climax and we see brief shot of Olympic flame being kirdled. Followed by several sexually allusive shots. Pole locks into socket; diver into water; a baton slowly changes hands; hammer thrower; javelin; sexual horse jumping shots; ending with Olympic flame slowly going out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAT and RIMMER in bed. She is dreamily sated.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: I think I've achieved a new personal best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRET is watching grandstand on T.V. Beside him is

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 69 70 57. CONTD. a bottle of beer with an obviously hand painted label reading "Fors Ale". Most of the furniture has gone. T.V. COMMENTATOR. The surprise upsat at the White City was the defeat of Olympic champion Pat Cartwright who trailed in a very tired fifth; she complained afterwards of stomach cramps. MRS. FERRET enters and sees FERRET on knees by screen Peering at show jumping. He springs back to the one remaining chair. MRS. FERRET switches off T.V.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FERRET
dialogues.text: Where's it all gone?

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: What? Where's what all gone?

dialogues.speaker: MRS, FERRET
dialogues.text: The furniture.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: Ah that ... yes well while you were out it started getting a bit shaky so I Popped it into the furniture shop to have it repawned ... repaired ... : He leans back with casual air. I rather like it like this ... great feeling of space. Care for a glass of Fors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACKET's Humber drives up and he gets out. The doorman opens the door for him,

dialogues.speaker: DOORMAN
dialogues.text: Nice to see you again so soon, sir. You know the way I imagine.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 70 71 wa wo cONTD.

dialogues.speaker: BLACRET
dialogues.text: Oh, ho, ho, yes.

dialogues.speaker: DOORMAN
dialogues.text: We thought of building you a flat upstairs, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKET
dialogues.text: Oh, no, no, very amusing ... because I'm here so often you mean? Ha, ha, ha. (to himself as he goes through door) Bloody Capricorns. Have a word with Charlie about him. A little regional unemployment I think. Ha, ha, ha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the drive a number of Bentley's cars including land- rover and 'Support Rhodesia’ and 'Save the Spofforths’ signs. Croquet is in progress. SIR ERIC BENTLEY,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER, HUTCHISON, SPOT, SIR ERIC'S NEPHEW, LADY VANYA,
dialogues.text: BENTLEY, NISS, BISHOP and MANDEVILLE. PAT is riding nearby. HUTCHISON walks up with MANDEVILLE.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Michael, have you met my dear friend Teddy Mandeville, Chancellor of the Exchequer any moment now, eh Teddy!

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: How nice to meet you in the flesh, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MANDEVILLE
dialogues.text: My pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Your Blacket idea is working very well,

dialogues.speaker: SPOT
dialogues.text: Even our gardener's sick of him. I mean he's never off the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope he doesn't die of over-exposure.

dialogues.speaker: SPOT
dialogues.text: (whinnies with laughter) Such a ghastly little man. Upper classwhinnies of agreement.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: He's a big help but you know what's going to decide the election. The race issue. We've got to be tougher with immigrants.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: I don't see how we can go any further than the Labour Party. We can't let in less than zero.

dialogues.speaker: SPOT
dialogues.text: We could let a few out ... I mean Uncle Eric had this ... super idea about a boat race ... £5,000 for the first West Indian to row back to Jamaica ... then they'd all sort of row off ...

dialogues.speaker: LADY VANYA
dialogues.text: (calling) Spot! Your shot?

dialogues.speaker: SPOT
dialogues.text: Oh, my shot. (leaves tc hit his ball) Coming, Auntie Vanya.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: As Six Eric is retiring in any case .. why don't you let him express his real views.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: But the man’s a lunatic. (looks at BENTLEY) Ah good shot Sir Eric.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Exactly ... he could make a grossly inflamatory speech ... you then sack him and emerge as a man of principle ... but the impression would still get about that we are tougher on immigration than Labour. RIMMER calls to NISS, chatting to PAT behind a tree, her horse grazing nearby.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Peter, if I could tear you away from my fiance for a moment ,.. I'd like ‘you to ring up a few newspapers. Blackcroquet ball is struck far, far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Notice saying "Budleigh Moor Conservative Association".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty hall except for BENTLEY's wife sitting at front with SPOT and many reporters and photographers clustered at back.

dialogues.speaker: SIR ERIC BENTLEY
dialogues.text: No one could accuse me of being a racialist. (SPOT cackles) (SIR ERIC glares) But when I hear stories as well authenticated as this which I got from a very close friend of a constituent who had been talking to somebody in a pub who'd heard from an extremely reliable source (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73 74 75 CONTD. SIR ERIC BENTLEY (Cont'd. ) that a frail old lady of 92 had been : locked in a lavatory by a group of ten immigrants who proceeded to poke at her with sharpened broomsticks over a period of fourteen hours whilst they chanted anti-white slogans and finally forced her to use a newspaper photograph of Mr. Enoch Powell in a way that I would rather not go into here ... when I hear stories like this I wonder "Are we mad?" To allow, in this country, frail old ladies to be ruthlessly poked by blacks. LADY BENTLEY and SPOT clap.

dialogues.speaker: SIR ERIC BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Now I'm no racialist but ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Race Uproar, BENTLEY hits out."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shadow Home Secretary HUGH WILTING is flapping in front of HUTCHISON. RIMMER is also present.

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: Have you read this filth?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, I have, dreadful. Dear oh dear!

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? I can't be Home Secretary in a party that condones racialism,.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: a No

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Don't worry Hugh. I shail act. I shall act. On matters of principle I am acting the whole time,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sits at his piano and tinkles away.

dialogues.speaker: RI RK
dialogues.text: Six Eric's announcing his retirement tonight.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: And Michael is taking over his seat at the General Election.

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: But that still leaves the impression that we're a lot of racialists.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Yes, well of course I admire your integrity, Hugh; but you must realise that we want to win this election and let's face it this isn't going to do us any harm.

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: It's no good, I must speak out,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: I don't think Tom wants another five years in opposition. Cold pause.

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: I don't care. I won't be muzzled.

dialogues.speaker: STREET. NIGHT. 76
dialogues.text: WILTING is walking down badly lit street when a large BLACK MAN appears from alleyway. CONTINUED ;  76 77 CONTD.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Hey, Whitey. .

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: You're trash man. (hits WILTING)

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: But I'm on your side, BLACK continues to beat him up.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: I got rhythm.

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: I understand your motives (thump) Now let's discuss this rationally. (thump) I'd do the same if I was you. (thump) Cool it, baby. (Knock out).

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. POLICE STATION. DAY. 77
dialogues.text: WILTING is bandaged and in wheel chair, being wheeled down corridor by POLICE SERGEANT. They go through door into Police Yard where a line of men, all white save his assailant. As WILTING is wheeled down the Line, all the suspects say the words "Hello Whitey" in varying accents. The BLACK MAN's accent is unmistakeable and very aggressive. WILTING reaches end of line.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Well, sir?

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: I couldn't swear to it ... but it might just possibly be the one in the green shirt.  78 79 80 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Post marriage rites; everyone cheering as RIMMER and PAT are about te get into car. PAT kisses her parents.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Bye, Mummy, Bye Daddy. NISS kisses PAT. RIMMER and PAT get into the car and drive off.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: (waving gaily) Calculating sod!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy couple in back seat of car.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: (kissing RIMMER) Right darling. Now where's this super secret surprise honeymoon?

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Ever heard of a little place called Budleigh Moor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAT and RIMMER appear to be sitting on a country stile holding hands. After a few seconds during which we think they've got away from it all, a battery of flash lights go off and we see masses of photographers. As we pull back we see that they are on a platform with "Budleigh Moor! banners,

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHERS
dialogues.text: Once more, kiss, Mrs. Rimmer ... look into his eyes ... Remember you're on honeymoon. Just one more like that ...

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: That'll be enough gentlemen. ig

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: . (to RIMMER) When are we going to get away from all these people.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: As soon as I get in darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Split screen rapid montage of election canvassing shots. With Simon and Garfunkel type music. RIMMER shaking hands, RIMMER kissing babies. RIMMER and PAT patting cows. Newspaper headlines reading: “Tories edge four per cent ahead since race flare up", RIMMER and PAT having tea in Grotty Cottage bravely drinking appalling tea. Both in pub playing darts. Various American touches to the campaign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.M. sitting in front of mirror, looking at palm of his hand as sexy girl makes him up.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKET
dialogues.text: Deirdre, would you say my career line comes to ab abrupt halt? No need to put much on my face I've got most of it left from this afternoon. Just a few drops in the eyes, get that lovable twinkle going ha, ha, ha and could you make the mouth a bit more generous please. INT. RIMMERS WORKOUT ROOM, PAT ON ROWING MACHINE. NISS°DRINKING. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: Keeping fit?

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: That's about all there is for me to do.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD.
dialogues.text: PAT gets off machine and lies down by NISS's feet and does bicycle exercises with her legs.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: I used to be pretty fit when I was in the army ... the only trouble was that it made me fantastically randy ...

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Oh it does.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: You must be pretty fit ... how's married life suiting you?

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: How should I know, I've hardly seen him since the ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: But whet about all those lovely pictures of you together in the papers.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: That's the only time we've been together when there's a photographer around.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: I must say there is a calculating side to Michael which I find rather «+» do you actually know anything about hin? Where does he come from?

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: He never talks about it to me ... just says he was found in the bulrushes (pause) You can't stand him, can you?

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: No, no, no, it’s not that ... but I don't like to see what he's doing to you.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: What he's not doing to me.

dialogues.speaker: INT, T.V. STUDIO, NIGHT. 84
dialogues.text: BLACKET in front of moving back projection of country scene. He is smoking a pipe and miming a country walk on a moving belt. The camera intercuts between BLACKET on the screen and @ reverse shot of BLACKET with the autocue he is reading and the B.P. clearly visible.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKET
dialogues.text: C.8, AUTOCUE "Warm smile". He smiles. Good evening. When you vote next week I'd like you to remember .,. C.S. AUTOCUE "Compassionate sincerity". That basically.you know friends, this election is not about money aud material things; it's about morality. The labour Party is nothing if it is not a moral crusade. C.S, AUTOCUE "Wry smile", It's hardly necessary to rewind you what we stand for. The Labour Party stands for ... well it stands for .. We see that the AUTOCUE has stuck. as we all know the Labour Party stands for ... as I don't think I need remind you ...for ... it stands for ... I'm not standing for any more of this ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84 85 CONTD. 68. BLACKET (Cont'd. ) . stop the cameras ... get the bloody man off the autocue.

dialogues.speaker: FLOOR MANAGER
dialogues.text: ' (stage whispering) It's live.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKET
dialogues.text: I know he's alive ... but I'm the Prime Minister not Sooty. Pull your finger out.

dialogues.speaker: FLOOR MANAGER
dialogues.text: (coming intc shot and whispering in BLACKET's ear) It's a live broadcast, they can see you.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKET
dialogues.text: What! Oooh! Ha, ha, ha. Oh dung ! BLACKET stops walking the belt continues and flings him through back projection screen,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RIMMER is wearing dark goggles and sitting under sunray lamp. HUTCHISON appears steaming from the sauna room,

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Well, Michael you've done a splendid job with Blacket,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: IT hope I can continue to do one. dips his toe into the pool and shivers.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: I've just been thinking about the composition of the Government and I've been trying to work out where your many talents would bear most fruit.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 85 CONTD,.

dialogues.speaker: . RIMMER
dialogues.text: Well, all my experience has been in financial matters, so I thought Chancellor of the Exchequer.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: My dear Michael. You're not even an M.P. yet. I admire your directness and drive, but as you must know, Mandeville will be in charge of the Exchequer.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Of course, L've always believed that a man's personal life is his own affair.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: You hadn't heard anything then?

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: No ... what is there to hear?

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Well ... I hate to spread gossip ... and they're probably faked in any case.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: What are faked?

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: The photographs I was sent.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Of Mandeville.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: And friends. But even if they're real I don't see why they should affect his efficiency at the Exchequer.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 85 86 87 CONTD. 2. HUTCHISON . Have you got ... these photographs with you ? RIMMER sits up, takes off his sungoggles and hands over a packet to HUTCHISON,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Yes ... I thought I'd better hand them over to you and say no more about it. (he does so) God knows where the negatives are. C.U. PHOTOGRAPH MANDEVILLE AS IN SC. 38. MANDEVILLE hangs upside down in cupboard.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: (peering at them) That's not Mandeville.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: The other way up.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Good God. The continental pig.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SC. 85, 87
dialogues.text: He looks at the rest of them, exclaiming the while.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Who sent you these?

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: It just said a friend.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: (looking at another) Geese, Christ! I may have to reconsider.  88 89 90 71.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSVENDOR
dialogues.text: Conservative Shadow Chancellor resigns; ill health given as reason; surprise appointment of Michael Rimmer; see page nine for in-depth profile of Tory whizz kid; paper sir?

dialogues.speaker: MANDEVILLE
dialogues.text: No thank you; you've told me all I want to know.

dialogues.speaker: INT, RIMMER'S DRAWING ROOM. NIGHT. 89
dialogues.text: HUTCHISON on T.V. Screen. Card saying: "A Party Political Broadcast on behalf of the Conservative Party.” HUTCHISON appears on screen.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: The next Conservative Government will reduce income tax, purchase tax and increase Old Age Pensions: This I solemnly pledge. Now to help you make up your minds here's a chance to take another look at the alternative to a Conservative government. BLACKET appears on the screen in a re-run of the end of his disastrous broadcast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NISS and PAT are playing scrabble and watching T.V. The BLACKET disaster is repeatedly re-run. NISS switches sound down.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: That was a bloody good idea of Michael's. The silent picture of BLACKET can be seen in the backgrou as they continue the game, lying down on the floor next t each other. The game is fairly well advanced, NISS looks at his letters.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: Ah, yes. Now what would be good now. (placing letters on board) Bed. B. E. D. Bed. (looks meaningfully)

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: That's eight to you and I'll make LOYALTY. (placing letters down)

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: Oh, that's a good word. Fifteen to you. Now how can I use my *X'. Ah, yas, I can get sex with the 'E' of Bed.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Ah, I can add U ... A... L oe Five to me.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: Ah, but you don't know what you've let yourself in for, I can use your Loyalty to get Sexuality. (adds letters IT)

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Well, all I can do is this. She puts the letters 'N' and 'O' down on a vacant part of the board.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: But you can't do that, it's not connected with anything.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Oh yes it is. Good night, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, TOWN, DAY. 91
dialogues.text: Polling Day. People ave walking into a Polling Booth.

dialogues.speaker: STUDIO. LONDON. NIGHT. 92
dialogues.text: HENCH standing in front of desk. aA Bank of T.¥, Monitors and huge scoreboard showing Conservative 0, Labour 0, Liberal 0, Others 0, and an enormous swingometer with the pointer at O. NISS, SCHUMANN and other figures are also in the studio.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: Good evening and welcome to Election Grandstand. The first result should be coming in quite soon from Clitheroe this is Hugh Wilting's seat and traditionally the first constituency to complete the counting, but first, with no results in let's ask David Schumann what he thinks of the situation. SCHUMANN (a Glaswegian) Frankly, Steven, Ithink we've started the programme about an hour too early.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: Ah, ha, ha, well let's go over to Freddie Daring in Clitheroe to see if there's any news yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FREDDIE DARING standing above a mass of furious counters and tellers. INT. T.V.

dialogues.speaker: DARING
dialogues.text: Well, these lads've got a great reputation to maintain and they're absolutely determined to give us the first result. I've never seen such fast hard counting and we should have something to tell you in a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: RENCH
dialogues.text: Thank you, Eddie, and now let's have one more look at the state of the parties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 95 96 CONTD. INT. T.V.
HENCH (Cont'd) That's the position at the moment with no results in yet and now perhaps we could get a reaction from New York. So over there now by Early Bird to Tom Stoddart.

dialogues.speaker: STODDART
dialogues.text: I'm not your Buddy, neither am I your mother ... appalling people. (he realises he is on the air) Ah yes, well, over here in New York we're all as they say over here ‘doggone keen' to hear the first result,

dialogues.speaker: HENCH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (over Stoddart's picture - shouting) So are we here in London, and we must go back up to Clitheroe as I think they may have something for us. In the background, on T.V., we see STODDART being mugged. 96

dialogues.speaker: DR. LUNS
dialogues.text: Here in Stockholm we are extremely excited.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: (V.0. shouting) We don’t want to talk to you at the moment, Dr. Luns, if we could talk to you later.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LUNS
dialogues.text: Oh, I wanted to tell you ...

dialogues.speaker: HENCH'S VOICE
dialogues.text: And so over to Freddie Daring in Clitheroe for the first result.  97 98 99 100 101

dialogues.speaker: DARING
dialogues.text: No, we don't have the result yet but in the closing minutes these lads are really going berserk, George Winthrop, one of the most experienced counters broke a finger just now but he's carrying on.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: Well, thank you Freddie. Well. still no resuits from Clitheroe, HENCH looks appealingly at NISS and SCHUMANN. They both shake their heads.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: In that case, let's rejoin our good friend Dr. Luns in Stockholm, Are you there Dr. Luns?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an empty chair and a FLOOR MANAGER.

dialogues.speaker: FLOOR MANAGER
dialogues.text: He is gonna to the errr. ‘ee will be back.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: In that case we'll go over to Paris where Pierre Du Bois is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parisian cafe where PIERRE DU BOIS is serving drinks in waiter's kit.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: Bon soir, Pierre.

dialogues.speaker: . PIERRE
dialogues.text: Bon soir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HENCH talking to monitor,

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: Pierre du Bois both the candidates at Clitheroe are keen supporters of the Common Market, what's the French reaction to this phenomenon.

dialogues.speaker: PIERRE
dialogues.text: Je comprends rien. Moi j m'en fou Salud. Service no compris.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: Ah, well, I'm not sure we've located the right Pierre du Bois. But while we were talking to Paris we did get the first result in, not from Clitheroe but from Beccles. And here it is. Card comes up on Screen. ORVILLE-GASPACHO (Conservative) 27,001. FOGGE (Labour) 10,744. Conservative Gain.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: A Conservative gain there Well, let's see what swing that is. Over to Magnus Orbison on the swingometer, The swingometer registers just under 20% to the Tories.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: Peter Niss.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: That's exactly the swing we predicted at Fairburn, but if repeated it will ive i jorit 65. give a Conservative majori y of 2 Seonrrnurp:  104 105 106 107 108 CONTD,.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: Well, now the results are coming in thick and fast, And here's an interesting result. Michael Rimmer has held Budleigh Moor for the Conservatives with a greatly increased majority. EXT. BUDLEIGH MOOR TOWN HALL. NIGHT. RIMMER and PAT waving from balcony.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: It won't be long now darling.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Tt hasn't been long for the last six weeks. INT, FERRET'S BARE LIVING ROOM. MR. and MRS, FERRET are watching television.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FERRET
dialogues.text: He's in, I knew he would do it.

dialogues.speaker: FERRET
dialogues.text: But only by 17,000. INT. T.V, STUDIOS. LONDON. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: So with 435 results we have the nws that the Prime Minister haa conceded defeat. INT. NO. 10 DOWNING STREET. NIGHT. BLACKET kicking in his T.V, set. 77. 105 106 107 108

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shot of Conservatives celebrating, on T.V. screens. Score ticking over. Plebs running in and out of studio with bits of paper. Clock now reads six fifteen in morning. Staff looking dead.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: And now at six fifteen there's only the Clitheroe result to come in, and here it is, after three recounts, Hugh Wilting has retained his seat with a majority of only 5, that's over 18,000 down from the last election, due no doubt to his courageous stand on the race issue. Now we leave election grandstand with a new Conservative Government in office. So it's my thanks to all our experts and good night. Exhausted everyone straggles out of the studio, the light go out, leaving a single monitor switched on, on which the patient figure of Dr. Luns is still sitting.

dialogues.speaker: LUNS
dialogues.text: Hello. Hello London. Lungs here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern faced and resolved group.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The P.M. is holding an emergency cabinet meeting at Chequers to discuss what he describes as the very grave financial situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start on champagne cork exploding. PULL BACK to Cabinet Ministers eating strawberries. They are giggling and chortling "we won". WILTING, now recovered save for tight arm in plaster-cast and sling; HUTCHISON, now P.M., stops the giggling. CONTINUED :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 111 CONTD. All rise. Rush from arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: so

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, the Chancellor will bring _the exact figures, but I think unless we announce strong measures, there is a great danger of another run on the pound.

dialogues.speaker: SNAGGOT
dialogues.text: Oh, I wonder if you'd excuse me for a moment. There's a rather important call I have to make to my wife in Zurich,

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I must ask you as patriots and Ministers not to speculate against the pound, the table is halted as RIMMER's helicopter RIMMER gets out and comes to table.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late. I wanted to make sure I had all the figures.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Good, well, we've just been discussing the appalling mess left to us by the Socialists. We have inherited a mess haven't we,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Good. Fine,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: All in all the financial situation could be described as disastrous.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Catastrophic.

dialogues.speaker: SNAGGOT
dialogues.text: Hopeless is another good one.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: I think we're all agreed to the nature of the problem. Now Michael, what proposals do you have to deal with this ... crisis.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Yes, crisis.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Well first of all I would reduce income tax, purchase tax, and increase Old Age Pensions.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: You must be mad.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: I think we have to fulfil our pre-election pledges.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: My dear Michael, nobody expects us to do that. (hear, hear) The normal thing is to say how staggered and horrified we all are and blame it on the last lot. I mean what are our gold reserves at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: 2% million.

dialogues.speaker: POTTER
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 111 CONTD. 3. All hands 8l.

dialogues.speaker: . HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: But seriously Michael ... what are your proposals,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Well, I've been having a word with our friends in Paris and Bonn.

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: I didn't know we had any friends in Paris 4d Bonn.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: So while I'm sorting things out I suggest you sit tight and do nothing for a couple of weeks.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Good idea, will all those in favour of doing nothing for two weeks raise one hand. go up save WILTING's who is incapacitated still.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: That's all I have to say, gentlemen, However, I do think we should give the impression of activity.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: What about a summit? That would pass the time.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Very good ... and we should talk in terms of keeping our options open and so on. Members of the Cabinet murmur agreement as they drift off

dialogues.speaker: BREAM
dialogues.text: An agonising reappraisal of the fiscal malaise.

dialogues.speaker: SNAGGOT
dialogues.text: Cutting out the red tape,

dialogues.speaker: POTTER
dialogues.text: Rooting out the dead wood,

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: Establishing a think tank,

dialogues.speaker: SNAGGOT
dialogues.text: Bomb Dresden.

dialogues.speaker: BREAM
dialogues.text: Put out peace feelers.

dialogues.speaker: SNAGGOT
dialogues.text: The only thing the Germans understand is a bomb on the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HUTCHISON surrounded by T.V. Cameras and PRESSMEN, He mounts steps to plane and waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On projection screen, in conference room, we see film of all the latest military equipment, rockets, etc. with commentary over in Dick De Keyser voice, Famous Generals, COLONEL MOFFAT, an Anglo-Scot, Air Marshals, Admirals and RIMMER, On the walls various signs including 'Be like Dad, keep mum' and ‘Careless talk costs lives.’ v.0. Britain's defences have been been stronger. Take a look at the unique British Hover bomb which hovers over the enemy issuing instructions to surrender. If not shown a white flag within 15 seconds it devastates 50 square miles.

dialogues.speaker: AIR MARSHAL NOBE
dialogues.text: I've never seen that, is it one of youre. V.0. Now feast your eyes on the giant new Caligula Missile Computer programmed to home in on specific targets, GEN STRIKE. I'VE never seen that one, is that one of yours? v.0. And if that isn't enough to strike fear into the hearts cf our enemies, what about this jolly little fellow; the navy's nuclear- powered Water Weasel ... when it's not annihilating our foes it's hard at work gathering fish.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL CRICHTON
dialogues.text: Well, I've never seen any of those.

dialogues.speaker: C.U. BRITISH FLAG, 114
dialogues.text: All this and more make British defences the envy of the world.

dialogues.speaker: C.U. QUEEN ON HORSEBACK. 115
dialogues.text: So for those who think that the British lion has lost its teeth, let them be warned that it can still give them a pretty nasty suck,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General murmur of 'What' 'Preposterous'

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: And now, just step on to the terrace please gentlemen. There are refreshments,

dialogues.speaker: CONTD.
dialogues.text: RIMMER leads them out of the room. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A model countryside is set upon the terrace with models of all the weapons we have just seen on film. Champagne and food are also on nearby tables. Service WAITERS to begin to serve the refreshments. MILITARY GUARDS ARE AT EACH END OF THE TERRACE.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: I think this answers your question, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: ATR MARSHAL NOBE
dialogues.text: But these are just models.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: And that's all we need; thanks to our film department we have the finest deterrent force in the world. Mumurs of "Disgraceful; shocking; rebarbative!! "Very good champagne’.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: This will save us approximately a billion a yeaz, enabling me to increase your own salaries by 100%.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL STRIKE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL CRICHTON
dialogues.text: Twice as much Willy.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL STRIKE
dialogues.text: "Mums the word', Mumurs of approval. A few begin to play with the models. GENERALS and company look a little puzzled but rather Pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign indicates that it is a germ warfare establishment. Biological Warfare Research Centre. Another sign says ‘Open Day'. Various visitors are wandering around. Buses with "Derby and Joan Club' signs are parked nearby. RIMMER and COLONEL MOFFAT with GUIDE pass sign "To The Streptococcatorium™.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass looking at old ladies and men watching various audio-visual sideshows.

dialogues.speaker: MECHANICAL VOICE
dialogues.text: If you look through the viewer, you'll be able to see these powerful little ereastures, romping about in their natural environment, in this case a stoat's lung. Chorus of 'OOOH!!*

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER MECHANICAL VOICE
dialogues.text: There's no cruelty involved here, and it is stressed that no British dogs are employed for experiments, wherever possible a human volunteer is used. OLD LADIES, Chorus of ‘Ooohs'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RIMMER, MOFFAT and GUIDE enter. SOLDIERS with guns guard entrances and doors of frigidaires. The room is full of "DANGER" signs and trays, boxes, etc., of germs, all marked with warning signs. Guide picka up a round dish with jelly in it:

dialogues.speaker: GUIDE
dialogues.text: Do you know, six, there's enough elephantiasis in here to wipe out China? Think of it, six hundred

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 122 CONTD. 87. . GUIDE (Cont'd.) bloaded Chinks rolling about the place.

dialogues.speaker: MOFFAT
dialogues.text: We could have done with that in Malaya.

dialogues.speaker: GUIDE
dialogues.text: You've got to laugh, sir, you need a sense of humour in this place.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Where's the Union Jacalli?

dialogues.speaker: GUIDE
dialogues.text: Over here, sir. GUIDE goes to the frigidaire, GUARD comes to attention as GUIDE takes out a tray of aerosols with Union Jack markings. Proudly,he places them on a bench.

dialogues.speaker: GUIDE
dialogues.text: There she is, sir, the Union Jacalli, our latest germ for peace; and incidentally a big dollar earner. And has gained the Queen's award for industry.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: And there's no known antidote?

dialogues.speaker: GUIDE
dialogues.text: Not as yet, sir; it's an extremely concentrated form of the common English cold. Acts in seconds - leaves no trace.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: That's the one for us, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. GUIDE lovingly replaces tray in Frigidaire.

dialogues.speaker: GUIDE .
dialogues.text: He's a right little bugger this one; once he's in there, there's no shifting him ... Like a Lager, sir?

dialogues.speaker: INT, U.S. PRESIDENT'S OFFICE. DAY. 123
dialogues.text: P.M. is nearer the head of the queue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long dining table laden with silver and regimental trophies; walls covered with tattered flegs, and regimental standards in corners of room, The Guest Night is in full swing. Everybody is drunk except for RIMMER, During the whole of the Proceedings, a SERGEANT PIPER walks round the table playing. All the OFFICERS are present, wearing mess kit and medals. We pan down the table hearing chance remarks about the Swiss and lots of military planning, with the salt cellars.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR MATHIESON
dialogues.text: (using salt cellars) Jamis's lot come in here ... Charles is over here ... then we all sweep in and wipe them out. Completely,

dialogues.speaker: CAPT, DUNSMUIR
dialogues.text: NO survivors,

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SCOTT
dialogues.text: No survivors? That's a bit rough, I'd better tell Mary right away.

dialogues.speaker: CAPT. DUNSMUIR
dialogues.text: No, sir. No survivors on their side.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SCOTT
dialogues.text: 4h. That's more like it,

dialogues.speaker: CAPT. DUNSMUIR
dialogues.text: Simple ... effective ... and bloody good gun. (They toast)

dialogues.speaker: CONTD.
dialogues.text: LT, WILLIAMSON picks up a canister of Union Jacalli.

dialogues.speaker: LT. WILLIAMSON
dialogues.text: (musing to himself) Better master the machinery. Know your weapon. How do these chaps work? Press firmly down with index finger. First ensuring that all ranks are wearing gas masks. LT. WILLIAMSON presses the spray and passes out. We track down to another conversation.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN FRASER
dialogues.text: The Swiss have been asking for it. I mean what self respecting nation can go for 500 years without a war.

dialogues.speaker: LT. STOPPARD
dialogues.text: The Swiss.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN FRASER
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: LT. STOPPARD
dialogues.text: "Nuff said. We reach MOFFAT and RIMMER.

dialogues.speaker: MOFFAT
dialogues.text: (barely controlling emotion) You see people have lost the old values of honour ... and decency,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Courage ... Comradeship.

dialogues.speaker: MOFFAT
dialogues.text: I can't tell you how grateful I am Michael, for this chance to do some- thing for Britain. You see ordinary people in this country are sick and tired of being pushed around,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 124 125 126 127 128 CONTD. 2. RIMMER . Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MOFFAT
dialogues.text: (suddenly shouting)

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT MAJOR
dialogues.text: The PIPER stops playing and stands behind the COLONEL. MOFFAT stands up. All follow suit.

dialogues.speaker: MOFFAT
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. Operation Cuckoo!!?

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Operation Cuckoo. God bless her, (they all drink) PIPER starts playing - music continues over next scene.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, SWISS SNOW CLAD MOUNTAINS. DAY. 125
dialogues.text: A peaceful scene. The scots music grows louder suddenly over & ridge, leap the ski-ing Spofforths in kilts, wearing tartan gas masks. The Spofforths OFFICERS are riding sno-mobiles.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, SWISS SNOW CLADD MOUNTAINS. DAY. 126
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP SHOTS of SPOFFORTHS' Tartan gas masks, skis. They ski superbly down towards the valley. EXT, GOTHIC CASTLE, A LA “WHERE EAGLES DARE", DAY. 127 The piping stops. Silence. A drum roll. Silence. A spate of sneezing and thuds of bodies falling on concrete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead SWISS GUARDS litter the floor holding tattered handkerchiefs, in great disarray.  129 130 131 132 133 134 135 ol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPOFFORTHS are opening gold vault door with resounding * clang.

dialogues.speaker: INT, CASTLE VAULTS, 130
dialogues.text: Mounds of shining gold bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPOFFORTHS are loading gold bars on to ski-trolleys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SPOFFORTH is sprawling the words ‘Viva El Fatah’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the sound of pipes the triumphant SPOFFORTHS are towed uphill and away with the gold laden radracks. Some SPOFFORTHS still ride sno-mobiles.

dialogues.speaker: INT, U.S. PRESIDENT'S OFFICE. DAY. 134
dialogues.text: We see the P.M. being shown into the office. Door closes. Five seconds later the P.M. comes out again,

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: Thank you, thank you. (waving at President) See you again soon.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT'S SECRETARY,
dialogues.text: Next.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, LONDON AIRPORT. NIGHT. 135
dialogues.text: At bottom of aeroplane stairs talking to TV and

dialogues.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
dialogues.text: I'd just like to say that my talks with the President were wide-ranging full and exhaustive.  136 137

dialogues.speaker: EXT, NEWSPAPER HEADLINES. DAY. 136
dialogues.text: Cut to newspapers whirling out with headlines reading "Gold From The Sea’ ~ Dazzling Prospects’ and ‘North Sea Gold. U.K. 0.K.?' Daily Mirror says ‘Bloody Marvellous, there's gold in them thar drills’. NEWSPAPER VENDOR on street corner.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSVENDOR
dialogues.text: North sea gold find confirmed! Read all about it! The Bank of England this afternoon announced that a massive new find of gold believed to be worth at least thirty billion pounds will enormously help to bolster Britain's reserve position. Mystery moves in Geneva as Swiss Government breaks off relations with Egypt. Paper, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MANDEVILLE
dialogues.text: Have you got the results of the 3.30?

dialogues.speaker: NEWSVENDOR
dialogues.text: Kentucky Lad 33-1 L. Piggot up. Paper, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MANDEVILLE
dialogues.text: No thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celebration scene. T.V. Cameras. PHOTOGRAPHERS are all crammed on to the rig which is surrounded by many small boats containing sightseers. Helicopters fly above. On the rig are HUTCHISON, RIMMER, WILTING, PAT, NISS, MOFFAT, other Members of the Cabinet and innumerable dignitaries. Cries from CAMERAMEN and NEWSPAPER MEN who are dominating the proceedings. AUDIENCE is clapping, SPOFFORTHS pipe band is playing. WILTING has noticeable limp and carries a stick.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: And its my pleasure to show you the first ingot to be mined from our vast North Sea Gold Field.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 137 93. CONTD. Applause: ‘Congratulations’ ‘Well done, sir’. He reaches down to pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: I'll give you a hand, sir. RIMMER and WILTING hand over ingot.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCHISON
dialogues.text: It's all right, Michael, Hugh I think its me they want. HUTCHISON picks up the very heavy ingot. PHOTOGRAPHERS clamour,.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHERS
dialogues.text: Could you hold it up, sir. A bit to the left Prime Minister. Look this way sir, A bit higher still, Prime Minister. In order to get their shots the PHOTOGRAPHERS are advanci on HUTCHISON who grins and attempts to raise the Ingot ab his head. He is backing gradually towards the edge of the rig.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHERS
dialogues.text: Above your head, sir, that's right ... a bit higher if you can. Like a weight-lifter, the straining HUWCHISON finally raises the ingot above his head in triumph. He slips. RIMMER goes towards him. The weight of the gold causes HUTCHISON to keel over backwards into the water. Still clinging to the gold he disappears from view. Only bubbles remaining. WILTING leans over the edge.

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: Let go of the gold sir, He is held back from jumping in, HUTCHISON is gone for ever.  G4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HENCH with WILTING, BLACKET and BISHOP OF COWLEY. They are chatting and drinking and giggling.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: Ha, ha, ha, I mean, I was quite fond of him, but what a stupid way to go, he, he.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKET
dialogues.text: Talk about - floating pound ...

dialogues.speaker: FLOOR MANAGER
dialogues.text: Quiet studio, quiet. Ten seconds, love. They all assume appropriate serious expressions and hide drinks. HENCH tries to sober up. Music comes up and HENCH is cued. Behind them on the back projection screen is a picture of the P.M. fondling a goat.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: (very serious) Tonight the country lies stunned by the tragic news of the death of the Prime Minister. A very slight snort from off camera is heard and HENCH breaks up just managing to convert it into an agonised expression of grief.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: Messages of sympathy have been pouring in from all over the world. The Pope has condemned the senseless violence of our times. The President of the U.S.A. spoke warmly of the man with whom he had recently spent so much time. Here in the studio tonight ere three men, who knew him well, First the Home Secretary, Hugh Wilting, who was with him when he died. Turns to WILTING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 138 CONTD. “9 a .

dialogues.speaker: WILTING .
dialogues.text: This is a black day ... or a darkish sort of day for Britain.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP OF COWLEY
dialogues.text: I think it ironic that a man who so loved the sea should be, so to speak bitten by the mouth that drowned him ... (pause) Was it St. Paul or Cole Porter who said ‘We always hurt the one who loves ug'. But I'm sure this fine man has found solace in heaven with Almighty God if there is such a person.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: Mr. Blacket you at times have been on somewhat acrimonious terms with the late Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKET
dialogues.text: We've had our differences.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: On one occasion, indeed several occasions, you described him as two-faced weasel- eyed git.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKET
dialogues.text: In the rough and tumble of Parliamentary debate one often says things that are easily misinterpreted. But there was always a great warmth between us. One hates to make party points but ...

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP OF COWLEY
dialogues.text: Suffer little ones and let the little ones suffer. He giveth and taketh away and casteth bread upon the waters.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: Well just lets take one more look at this tragic accident.

dialogues.speaker: CONTD. 2.
dialogues.text: 139 In slow motion, picture comes up of HUTCHISON edging nearer side of the rig.

dialogues.speaker: HENCH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Here we see the Prime Minister moving to one side ta give the photographers a better view of the gold. At the crucial moment when HUTCHISON slips, the picture is partially obscured by a cameraman. RIMMER moves towards HUTCHISON. The action is frozen!

dialogues.speaker: HENCH, (V,.0.)
dialogues.text: This is the crucial moment; the Prime Minister slips; Michael Rimmer rushes to his side but is unable to save him. Action starts again and though the events are ebscured by foreground figures, it looks as if HUTCHISON may well have been pushed rather than pulled by RIMMER. We follow HUTCHISON into sea and stay with the bubbles,

dialogues.speaker: HENCH
dialogues.text: But even so soon after the tragedy, the question en everybody's lips is ‘Who will succeed?

dialogues.speaker: BREAM
dialogues.text: I can't say I like the man,but you must admit he's got something.

dialogues.speaker: POTTER
dialogues.text: I can't say I like the man, but I Must admit he's got something. How about you Mandeville.

dialogues.speaker: MANDEVILLE
dialogues.text: I can't say I like the man but I must admit he's got something on me.  140 ‘9

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FERRET is riding along on a cycle. A transistor radio is hanging from the handlebars on Which we hear the Jimmy Young Show in progress. Music ends.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY YOUNG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Time for our midmorning phone call ... orft we go .. We hear dialling tone.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FERRET, (V,0.)
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY YOUNG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Ferret?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FERRET, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That's right Jimmy’... but Ethel to you.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY YOUNG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What do you do, Ethel?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FERRET, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Just an ordinary housewife.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY YOUNG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And what does your husband work at?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FERRET, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My husband, Jimmy ... he's a failure. FERRET falls of bike into ditch; radio lands on marshy ground and slowly sinks. FERRET lies beside it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY YOUNG, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Ho, ho, ho ... as an ordinary housewife, who would yeu choose to lead the Censervatives,.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FERRET, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Oh, Michael Rimmer, Jimmy; he's everything my husband isn't. The radio disappears into mud.  141 142 98.

dialogues.speaker: INT, HOUSE OF COMMONS. CORRIDOR. 141
dialogues.text: BREAM is walking along corridor with SNAGGOT,

dialogues.speaker: SNAGGOT
dialogues.text: He's ruthless, opportunistic, dishonest, shallow, evasive, unprincipled, but I'm still not sure that he'll make a good leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAT RIMMER is in the bath and RIMMER comes in and starts dabbing after shave on himself.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Don't wait up for me this evening, darling, I'll be vather late. PAT soaks herself sullenly.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: (kissing her on forehead) Bye darling. He reaches the door. when she says.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: I want a divorce,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: A divorce, why?

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: To put it in terms you'd understand, sexually speaking we're 70% below the national average.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: I know that darling, but you shouldn't pay too much attention to one month's figures, season variations are very misleading.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: I mean it Michael, I want a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: That's normal. Forty two per cent ef married women go through this phase in the first year of marriage.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: How do you think it would affect your chances of being Prime Minister if I went on television tonightand told everybody what a cold, unfeeling robot you are.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: You won't do that,

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: I'll ring Steven Hench now ... he'd love to get you.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: No you won't. Bye. 143°.4 INT. DRAWING ROOM. NIGHT. 143 RIMMER steps outside and locks bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Peter! NISS appears.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Pat's a little upset. Look after her and don't let her near a phone till I get back. PAT is calling through door to NISS.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Let me out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, CONSERVATIVE H,Q. NIGHT. 144
dialogues.text: RIMMER's car arriving at Conservative Party's Central Office. He is greeted by supporters. INT. RIMMER‘'S DRAWING ROOM, NIGHT. 145 PAT is hurling herself against door.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: Don't do that you'll bruise your lovely shoulders,

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: If you loved me you'd let me out.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: I do love you.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: And I love you so let me eut you stupid, spineless, sycophantic ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RIMMER has arms raised in victory.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: If you let me out you can have me. NISS lets PAT out and tries to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: Darling Pat, She kicks NISS and rushes past towards phone in living room, As she picks it up she sees RIMMER on T.V. accepting victory. INT, RIMMER ON T.V. NIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: May I say how privileged I am to be elected Leader of the Conservative Party. (Cheers!)  149 150 151 152

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: Christ, he's done it,

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: So he has ... sorry darling ... duty calls, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: ee. under circumstances that I most bitterly regret, this is not time for false hopes. The situation is critical and I intend to take immediate action.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER'S BEDROOM. NIGHT. 151
dialogues.text: RIMMER enters. INT.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Hello darling, now let's start improving our monthly figures,

dialogues.speaker: BALLROOM. NIGHT, 152
dialogues.text: RIMMER is introducing his cabinet to the Party faithful and T.V. cameras. Included amongst them are, NISS, MANDEVILLE and MOFFAT who has just been introduced. We see him smiling, with the caption over reading "MINISTER OF DEFENCE’, RIMMER (Cont 'd.) Alexander Mandeville will be Minister of Labour. MANDEVILLE smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Now happily recovered from his illness I have selected him because above all Alexander is a deeply human man.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 152 CONTD. MANDEVILLE smiles a little nervously. RIMMER (Cont 'd.) And no one knows more than I how very human he can be. Caption 'Minister of Labour’ over the slightly embarrasse picture of MANDEVILLE.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: As Public Opinion Polls have become so vital a part of our democratic way of life, the time has come to take them out of private hands where they could possibly be misused, I have, therefore, created a National Poll board under the Chairmanship of Peter Niss. NISS smiles modestly. I have chosen him not because he is a personal friend of myself and my wife, but because he brings that added dimension of knowing how best to keep open the lines of communication between you the people and us, your servants. NISS smiles. Now you know that I have never sought power ... and now that I have power I want to share it with you; for it is you, the people of Britain who have made this country great ... as Winston Churchill said 'You are the lion, I merely provide the roar’; and from now on I want to consult you directly. On every major issue there will be a referendum in which you may vote; so at last we will have a real democracy, Good night. Applause. PAT moves towards RIMMER.

dialogues.speaker: PAT
dialogues.text: That was marvellous; did you really Mean it?

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, PARALLEL SUBURBAN STREETS. DAY. 153
dialogues.text: Fleet of Post Office vans drive up with military precision and peel off down each street. Several POSTMEN emerge from each van with large bundles. They make their way down garden paths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. SPIMM is at table filling in form, MRS. SPIMM who we saw earlier with CRODDER is watching delightedly as second delivery arrives.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SPIMM
dialogues.text: Soh look .., there's more coming ... isn't it nice ... It makes me feel so important.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SPIMM
dialogues.text: We are important Loretta, a vital cog. Hats off to Rimmer. Now then...Should we keep a continuing military presence in Binwandi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUMER is conducting a communal Vote in. The AUDIENCE is mainly women, Posters on wall. 'Think before you vote', "You're in charge', Band is playing. Audio controlled Talkback type Swingometer on Podium. PUMER dances onto PODIUM and speaks into microphone. Music stops.

dialogues.speaker: PUMER
dialogues.text: Thank you maestro ... all having a good time at the Votein.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Yes, (they cheer)

dialogues.speaker: PUMER
dialogues.text: Right ... a little bit of fun on the continent ... foreign affairs. ALL (cheer)

dialogues.speaker: PUMER
dialogues.text: Seriously theugh Ladies and Gentlemen ... tonight's star vote ... the Common Market negotiating table ... now think very carefully, remember its your vote, and your vote counts. The Common Market negotiating table ... let's hear it for Scandinavian Pine. There is subdued clapping. Swingometer registers 3%,

dialogues.speaker: PUMER
dialogues.text: That's three per cent for the pine ... and now let's hear it for geod old British oak. Huge cheers and clapping. Swingometer reads about 70.

dialogues.speaker: PUMER
dialogues.text: That's 70 for British oak and now last of all ... how about Formica, The audience gasp ... a moment's pause and then pandemoni of enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Formica, formica. SWINGOMETER reads maximum decibel level. PUMER is mobbed by enthusiastic crowd.

dialogues.speaker: MANDEVILLE
dialogues.text: Whole country's gone mad!

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: Mad!

dialogues.speaker: BREAM
dialogues.text: The public don't know anything about the Government. What does he think he's doing?

dialogues.speaker: MANDEVILLE
dialogues.text: He's off his head,

dialogues.speaker: BREAM
dialogues.text: I suppose there's one advantage, at least we can hardly fail to stay in power,

dialogues.speaker: MANDEVILLE
dialogues.text: Power? What Power, the: public have got all the power, Everyone's gone mad,

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: Are you going to resign?

dialogues.speaker: MANDEVILLE
dialogues.text: I'm not mad. They are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. SPIM is sealing up last of buff envelopes. There is a huge pile of them ready to be posted. Theyare in nightclothes.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SPIMM
dialogues.text: That's done ... bedtime. I think, I think I was right to take a firm line on China, He starts to go upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SPIMM
dialogues.text: Oh yes ... you had to,

dialogues.speaker: CONTD.
dialogues.text: A red light flashes on TV from newly installed machine A noise like a miniature fire siren,

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SPIMM
dialogues.text: Oh quick, it's an emergency tellyvote. They watch TV screen avidly.

dialogues.speaker: T.V., (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hello again, the Government would like to know your feelings on water pollution,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NISS and RIMMER are lounging about reading some of the replies to the referenda.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: Here's a good way of reducing tension in the Near East.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: What's that.

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: Shoot Nasser. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: There's one here suggesting a pre- emptive nuclear strike against Northern Ireland,

dialogues.speaker: NISS
dialogues.text: Ignorant gits.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: It's going very well. Can you think of anything more boring than water pollution?

dialogues.speaker: PAT .
dialogues.text: What's that for?

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: I thought it was time you felt the smack of firm Government.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Standby ... ready Prime Minister? They signal their readiness.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Turn over.

dialogues.speaker: SCUNDMAN
dialogues.text: Running.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Action, RIMMER and PAT walk arm in arm,

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: As your Prime Minister, I hope I've never been afraid to admit my own mistakes, In every way the country is booming but I must admit that our experiment in participatory democracy seems to have run into difficulties perhaps I was too idealistic and in this modern world we may well need a more streamlined form of Presidential Government. You must let me know if you share this feeling. Next a week, you will have the chance to tell me, in what could be, if it is your wish, the last referendum for sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RIMMER is reading newspaper headlines reading 'RIMMER

dialogues.speaker: PROMISES PRESIDENTIAL REFERENDUM, NO MORE AFTER THIS',
dialogues.text: when WILTING bursts in, CONTINUED:  164 165

dialogues.speaker: JAG
dialogues.text: 167 Lil.

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: I've read this Referendum. What you're suggesting is nothing more or less than a dictatorship.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Hugh, like everyone else, you will have an opportunity of voting against it. It's quite democratic.

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: But what you don't realise is that 90% of the population are idiots.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: You said it, Hugh.

dialogues.speaker: WILTING
dialogues.text: You won't get away with this, Rimmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Placard saying 'It's President Rimmer. 82% say yes.' “XT. HIGH LONDON STREET, DAY. 166 Cheering crowds as RIMMER and PAT drive along in - an open limousine. NISS, MOFFAT, MANDEVILLE, etc. are all in cars behind. Muzzle of gun protruding from unfinished office building about eighteenth floor, RIMMER seen through sights from GUNMAN 's P.0.V. It wavers in its aim. Pull back to show that the gunman is FERRET, desperately trying to get RIMMER in his sights. He is leaning right over the window still aiming almost vertically down. He leans further and further and further,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The demented figure of HUGH WILTING with a smoking bomb in his bandaged hand rushes out of a doorway shrieking 'Venceremos' he hurls himself tuwards RIMMER's limousine, As he is about to reach car he shouts 'We shall overcome’ and draws back to frat] bomb.
